Oooooooh. Not the best news.
Revlog is simply a file that lists all objects like changesets (commits) and manifests (file list). Delta is a binary diff.

> Mercurial author wrote a paper on the revlog format, don't know if you need this (don't even know what the heck revlog and delta is): https://www.mercurial-scm.org/wiki/Presentations?action=AttachFile&do=view&target=ols-mercurial-paper.pdf

He speaks about bdiff there. Reading its docs.

> He speaks about bdiff there. Reading its docs.

Doesn't look like what I see, at least when I google for bdiff.

From Mercurial source code:
```cpp
/*
 mpatch.c - efficient binary patching for Mercurial

 This implements a patch algorithm that's O(m + nlog n) where m is the
 size of the output and n is the number of patches.

 Given a list of binary patches, it unpacks each into a hunk list,
 then combines the hunk lists with a treewise recursion to form a
 single hunk list. This hunk list is then applied to the original
 text.

 The text (or binary) fragments are copied directly from their source
 Python objects into a preallocated output string to avoid the
 allocation of intermediate Python objects. Working memory is about 2x
 the total number of hunks.

 Copyright 2005, 2006 Matt Mackall <mpm@selenic.com>

 This software may be used and distributed according to the terms
 of the GNU General Public License, incorporated herein by reference.
*/
```

Interestingly:

From `bdiff.c` of Mercurial:
```cpp
/*
 bdiff.c - efficient binary diff extension for Mercurial

 Copyright 2005, 2006 Matt Mackall <mpm@selenic.com>

 This software may be used and distributed according to the terms of
 the GNU General Public License, incorporated herein by reference.

 Based roughly on Python difflib
*/
```

Both libraries were written by Matt Mackall.

> Here's a Javascript implementation of python difflib: https://github.com/cemerick/jsdifflib

Maybe that's what I am looking for.
Looks like jsdifflib (and Python difflib, too) can only diff and cannot patch. Perhaps that's why there is also `mpatch.c` in hg.

This is RevlogNG, a format of `.i`/`.d` files, which I already know how to parse. I can parse them, seek to a specific revision and read some info. So, undeltified data can be easily read. What I don't know how to do is to parse deltified data. (basically, a subformat of RevlogNG)

@Krixano, big thanks!! It is not a full manual, but those lines gave me an idea about the format. So, the format is:

Delta is made of chunks. Lots of chunks.
Chunk is: 4 byte `start`, 4 byte `end`, 4 byte `length` and then `content` of `length` bytes. Each chunk should be read as: remove bytes from `start` to `end - 1` (inclusively), then insert `content` instead.

Another note: `start` and `end` refer to positions in source string, not resulting. So you can get something like this:

```
0 0 51 fdsjkhgkjfdhgjkldfhslhsdgkhsdfg(50 bytes)
50 98 48 hgfhgfhgf(48 bytes)
```

Which means: copy source string, then add 51 bytes to the beginning, then change bytes 50+51 -- 98+51 to those 48 bytes.

I need some help here. With git, there is no way to find out where branch diverged. For example:

```
* <- feature (want to merge to master)
|
*
|
*
|
* <- master
|
*
|
*
```

or

```
* <- feature (want to merge to develop)
|
*   * <- develop
|  /
* *
|/
* <- master
|
*
|
*
```

1. First problem is solvable: Git Center doesn't allow user to choose which branch to merge **to**.
2. Second problem: I believe GitHub does `git merge-base` and then shows diff `git diff feature $(git merge-base develop feature)`. So I have to write `merge-base` for myself.

Any other ideas or possibilities?

I often use technique `rebase-and-merge-no-ff`. Though I am now talking about how Git Center should parse this.

First, I saw that some links/images in ZeroNet repository were prefixed with `/` and were relative to repository. So I added a check for `/` and `./` prefixes to both `[]()` and `![]()`. So my fix adds `/gitcenter.bit` and `/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t` to ignore list.

Back then I added `/` and `./` checks to both `[]()` and `![]()` handles, but didn't replace `link` with `href`. So there should be no error now.

Moreover, I can replace `/path` with `/gitcenter.bit/repo/file/?repository_address/path`. But I can't do the same with links. So I decided to show placeholder first and then manually load image.

> While there's probably a way to do that manually (?)

You can `git push --force`.

> ideally, initial clone from git address

That is possible, though doing that in browser... Maybe, but I'm not sure.

> but even simply creating empty repo that can be pushed to would be fine

I'm sorry but that is not possible. I mean, ZeroNet doesn't know anything about directories. Instead, it uses files. So file `a` and `b/c` mean `file a and directory b with c inside it`. So empty directories won't be noticed by ZeroNet.

That means I can't create an empty directory. `git` requires a directory `data` to exist. Perfectly empty, though that can be bypassed.

But `git` also required `refs/heads` being empty in empty repository, so this is not possible.

---

Though if there is a possibility, I would implement it. Not closing it right now, because maybe this can be bypassed.

Hello.

Right now there is no way to subscribe to some issue - you can only watch over the whole project. To do that, you can press `follow issues and pull requests in newsfeed` button on `Issues` or `Pull requests` page. Subscription to only one issue is not yet implemented but in TODO, so I am not closing this as duplicate.

> git push http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GitLiXB6t5r8vuU2zC6a8GYj9ME6HMQ4t/repo/?1KR7WWJZwdezqEdSCPtChQGVdfgnBVhMPK

Instead, do:

```
git remote add zeronet ~/ZeroNet/data/1KR7WWJZwdezqEdSCPtChQGVdfgnBVhMPK/name_of_your_repo.git # Path to ZeroNet
git push zeronet --force
```

> Is planned some feature which will allow importing github respository to gitcenter directly, just by entering github .git URL? Or importing .zip / tgz archive?

It is planned, though I am not sure if importing via WebSocket will be fast.

You wanted to run `git ...` and you tried `127.0.0.1:43110`, so that probably means you have ZeroNet installed on Linux server - so you could download 1KR7WWJZwdezqEdSCPtChQGVdfgnBVhMPK and run git commands.

You need ZeroNet client to do a push, so if you don't have ZeroNet installed on that machine, you'll have to copy the repo to Windows and run `git push` there.
Do you have ZeroNet on linux? I'm asking because I didn't use headless Linux at all.

First, make your ZeroNet download Git Center:

```bash
$ curl -H "Accept: text/html" http://127.0.0.1:43110/gitcenter.bit
```

Now download your repository:

```bash
$ curl -H "Accept: text/html" http://127.0.0.1:43110/1KR7WWJZwdezqEdSCPtChQGVdfgnBVhMPK
```

Now you can add repository and push like this:

```
$ git remote add gitcenter /home/ZeroBundle/ZeroNet/data/1KR7WWJZwdezqEdSCPtChQGVdfgnBVhMPK/your_repository_name.git
$ git push gitcenter
```

Now sign and publish repository:

```
$ python /home/ZeroBundle/ZeroNet/zeronet.py siteSign 1KR7WWJZwdezqEdSCPtChQGVdfgnBVhMPK privatekeyofyoursite
$ python /home/ZeroBundle/ZeroNet/zeronet.py sitePublish 1KR7WWJZwdezqEdSCPtChQGVdfgnBVhMPK
```

You should be able to access repository now.

This is rather difficult to implement, because any user can create a repo with any ID. If the ID is unique to user, creating two issues with the same ID does harm only to the user, but if the ID is unique to the repository, it'll create a lot of problems.
A great idea!
We could add ZeroMe, Twitter, etc. -- is that what you mean?
However, there are tabs called `Issue` and `Pull request` which you can open.

Cloning and fetching via URL is supported already, it's just not documented.

Pushing, signing and publishing automatically is literally impossible without significant changes to ZeroNet core. What makes it even more difficult is that this would mean that ZeroNet will have to execute my code, which might be unsafe.

issues.title: Easy to create directory with empty name
issues.body: How to reproduce: type `/css/index.css` instead of `css/index.css` and an empty-name directory with `css` directory will appear.

issues.title: File name sorting
issues.body:
By @parkour86:

> Feature Request: Right now files are sorted alphabetically under `Root >`. I'd like to see directories sorted first then all other files sorted second.

issues.title: Show issue/PR id
issues.body: Show ID in issue list, e.g. #1@1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di

issues.title: Wrong count of stars is shown on Repository Index
issues.body: For example, `ZeroNet` repository has 20 stars, while on repository index it has 22.

issues.title: TODO: Difference between GitHub and Git Center
issues.body:
- [ ] Feedlist on Git Center (not on ZeroHello)
- [ ] Tag repositories and search by tags
- [ ] Show issue/PR count in tab
- [ ] Show statistics: commit count
- [ ] Search issues/PRs
- [ ] Issue/PR templates
- [ ] Wiki
- [ ] Notifications
- [ ] Linking PRs/issues (`this issue was mentioned _here_`)

issues.title: Everyone can edit tags or close/open issue
issues.body: Well, not change something, but anybody can add messages `... added tag ...` or `... closed issue` (it won't get closed in fact)

issues.title: Split Beginner's Guide to several how-to's
issues.body: Tried to simplify that guide to make it beginner's, but meanwhile this guide lost much helpful info. Splitting that guide to several and meanwhile writing other tutorials would be helpful.

issues.title: Reactions
issues.body: Add some reactions like `hooray`, `love`, `hate`, etc. for issues, pull requests and comments, like on GitHub.

issues.title: Redirect to address of site
issues.body: @ZeroLSTN has set up `repo.zerolstn.bit` address for repository, so now repository redirects to `/gitcenter.bit/repo/?repo.zerolstn.bit`.
